parts: According to the most established theories, how long will the universe last until the last stars are extinguished or turn into stellar cores / black holes, and what will be the state of the universe then?

According to our best current astrophysical models, the “last star” era will end extraordinarily far into the future — long after the universe has become cold, dark, and sparse by present standards. The timeline depends on the types of stars involved, because low-mass red dwarfs can burn for trillions of years, far longer than our Sun.  

---

## 1. Timescale for the Last Stars

In the **ΛCDM (Lambda Cold Dark Matter) cosmological model** with standard stellar evolution theory:

- **Massive stars** (O, B types) die quickly — within millions of years — but they’re long gone after the first few billion years.
- **Sun-like stars** last ~10 billion years before becoming white dwarfs.
- **Low-mass red dwarfs** (0.1–0.3 solar masses) dominate the late stellar population because they burn fuel extremely slowly and are common.
- The very smallest red dwarfs will still be shining after **~10–20 trillion years**.  
  The slowest burners may survive up to **~100 trillion years** (10¹⁴ years).

Once these are gone, no new natural star formation will occur because interstellar gas will be locked in stellar remnants (white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes), and cooling processes will prevent large-scale gravitational collapse of new stars.

---

## 2. State of the Universe at That Point

When the **last stars fade** (≈10¹⁴ years after the Big Bang):

- **Temperature:** The cosmic microwave background will have cooled to **~10⁻³ K** or less, far colder than today’s 2.7 K.
- **Matter distribution:** Galaxies will be gravitationally bound “island” structures or merged into single giant remnants due to galaxy mergers; most will be full of stellar remnants rather than luminous stars.
- **Light sources:** The only visible light will come from:
  - Occasional collisions or mergers of stellar remnants (e.g., white dwarfs merging into new stars for brief periods — but these will be rare).
  - Accretion events around black holes.
  - Possibly proton decay radiation (if proton decay occurs).
- **Main constituents:** White dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes, and cold planetary bodies.

---

## 3. What Comes After

After the **Stelliferous Era** (star-forming epoch) ends:

- **Degenerate Era** (~10¹⁴ to 10⁴⁰ years):  
  White dwarfs will cool into black dwarfs (not “black holes,” but cold, dark remnants).  
  Neutron stars will also cool.  
  If protons decay (as suggested by some grand unified theories), all baryonic matter will eventually disintegrate into radiation and leptons within ~10³⁴–10⁴⁰ years.
- **Black Hole Era** (~10⁴⁰ to 10¹⁰⁰ years):  
  Black holes will be the last massive objects, slowly evaporating via Hawking radiation.  
  The largest supermassive black holes will last up to **~10¹⁰⁰ years**.
- **Dark Era** (after ~10¹⁰⁰ years):  
  The universe will contain only extremely low-energy photons, neutrinos, electrons, and positrons, in a near-perfect vacuum.

---

**In summary:**  
The last naturally burning star will likely die about **100 trillion years** from now. By then, the universe will be a dark, freezing expanse, with only dead stellar remnants and occasional rare energetic events, on its long path toward complete thermodynamic equilibrium.

---

If you’d like, I can chart out the **full cosmological future timeline** from now until the Dark Era, with key dates and phases according to standard physics — including speculative events like proton decay and quantum tunneling of black dwarfs. That would give a complete picture of the universe’s post-stellar fate.
Quantify the difference between 10^14 and 10^100 in a way that appeals to a general audience and is interesting

To make the gulf between \(10^{14}\) and \(10^{100}\) intuitive for a general audience, it helps to translate the raw numbers into **human-scale analogies** and **stacked comparisons** — because otherwise our brains just shut down when faced with so many zeroes.  

---

### 1. Raw Scale Difference
The difference is not additive — it’s multiplicative.  

\[
\frac{10^{100}}{10^{14}} = 10^{86}
\]

That’s an **86-order-of-magnitude gap**. In other words, \(10^{100}\) is not “a bit bigger” — it’s **10,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 times bigger**.

---

### 2. Time Analogy
- \(10^{14}\) seconds is about **3 million years** — already mind-boggling on human scales.
- \(10^{100}\) seconds is about **3 × 10⁹² years**.

That’s so far beyond the age of the universe (\(\sim 1.38 \times 10^{10}\) years) that if you tried to reach \(10^{100}\) years by stacking **entire current universe lifetimes end-to-end**, you’d need to repeat our universe’s age **ten quadrillion quadrillion quadrillion quadrillion quadrillion quadrillion quadrillion times**.  

---

### 3. Particle Count Analogy
The **estimated number of atoms** in the observable universe is about \(10^{80}\).  

If you had one atom for each year, you could only just count up to \(10^{80}\) years. That’s still **20 orders of magnitude short** of \(10^{100}\) years. You’d need **a hundred universes full of atoms** to even get close to counting that high.

---

### 4. Sand Grains Story
Imagine:
- Start with one grain of sand.
- Every billion years, double the pile.
- To reach \(10^{14}\) grains takes **just** a few hundred doublings.
- To reach \(10^{100}\) grains would take **hundreds more doublings**, but each step after the first hundred would require **more sand than all the beaches on Earth combined** — over and over and over.

By the end, you’re talking about a pile of sand so large that it would need **a universe billions of light years across** just to hold it — and you’d still be nowhere near \(10^{100}\) times bigger than \(10^{14}\).

---

### 5. The Takeaway Metaphor
If \(10^{14}\) years is like a **single human heartbeat** in the timeline of black hole evaporation, then \(10^{100}\) years is the **entire lifetime of a trillion universes** one after another.  

The gap isn’t just big — it’s so big that ordinary comparisons collapse. We can describe it, but not truly *feel* it.  

---

If you’d like, I can put this into a **visual logarithmic “cosmic timeline” diagram** showing where the last stars go out (\(10^{14}\) years) and where black holes evaporate (\(10^{100}\) years), so the sheer gulf becomes more striking. Would you like me to do that?
If 10^14 is one second, how long ias 10^100?

If we take **\(10^{14}\) as one second**, then **\(10^{100}\)** is:  

\[
\frac{10^{100}}{10^{14}} = 10^{86} \ \text{seconds}.
\]

---

### Converting \(10^{86}\) seconds into something more tangible

1. **Seconds to years**  
There are about \(3.15 \times 10^7\) seconds in a year, so:  

\[
10^{86} \ \text{seconds} \div 3.15 \times 10^7 \ \text{s/year} \approx 3.17 \times 10^{78} \ \text{years}.
\]

---

### 2. Comparison to the Age of the Universe  
The universe is about \(1.38 \times 10^{10}\) years old.  

\[
\frac{3.17 \times 10^{78} \ \text{years}}{1.38 \times 10^{10} \ \text{years}} \approx 2.3 \times 10^{68}
\]

That means:  
If **1 second = \(10^{14}\)** in our analogy, then \(10^{100}\) is **about 230,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000** times the *entire age of the universe*.

---

### 3. Fun analogy  
If \(10^{14}\) is **one second**, then \(10^{100}\) is like saying:  
> “Wait a second… and then wait for a time longer than the age of the universe repeated **ten trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion times**.”  

That’s so much longer that even if every atom in the universe had been keeping time since the Big Bang, none of them would be close to counting that high yet.

---
